docs.snippet: The ship Abby Brown, Capt. O. L. BEARSE, lately arrived at this port from Marseilles, after having narrowly escaped total shipwreek in mid Ocean by the loss of her rudder and springing a lonk. The protracted trials of the skill and courage of Capt...
docs.lead_paragraph: The ship Abby Brown, Capt. O. L. BEARSE, lately arrived at this port from Marseilles, after having narrowly escaped total shipwreek in mid Ocean by the loss of her rudder and springing a lonk. The protracted trials of the skill and courage of Capt BEARSE during this tedious voyage, and the manner in which he mastered the difficulties of his position,

headline.main: NEW -YORK CITY; Twenty Days Mid-Ocean Without a Rudder

docs.snippet: The propeller Westernport, BERRY, from Portland, with merchandise to H. B. CROMWELL, came up yesterday, as usual, via Sandy Hook. These steamers are compelled by the closing of navigation through the Vineyard Sound to pass to the south of Nantucke...
docs.lead_paragraph: The propeller Westernport, BERRY, from Portland, with merchandise to H. B. CROMWELL, came up yesterday, as usual, via Sandy Hook. These steamers are compelled by the closing of navigation through the Vineyard Sound to pass to the south of Nantucket. Captain Berry reports that on the 17th he saw the schooner Emeline, for Marblehead, in the ice on Nantucket Shoals.

docs.snippet: The Cunard steamship Africa, Captain SHANNON, from Liverpool, about 10 A. M. of Saturday, April 5, arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon about 5 o'clock. The following from Lloyd's List may or may not have reference to the Pacific: FIGURIRA, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Cunard steamship Africa, Captain SHANNON, from Liverpool, about 10 A. M. of Saturday, April 5, arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon about 5 o'clock. The following from Lloyd's List may or may not have reference to the Pacific: FIGURIRA, March 24, 1856.

headline.main: FOUR DAYS LATER FROM EUROPE.; THE PEACE. IMPORTANT DISCLOSURE OF THE PROCEDINGS OF THE PROCEEDING OF THE CONFERENCES. OUR PARIS CORRESPONDENCE. THE DIFFICULTIES BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND ENGLAND. Loss of the Australian Steamer Schomberg. INTERESTING FROM INDIA AND CHINA. PROCLAIMATION OF PEACE IN RUSSIA. IMPORTANT DISCLOSURES OF THE PROCEEDINGS OF THE CONFERENCES. ARRIVAL OF THE AFRICA. OUR PARIS CORRESPONDENCE. ARRIVAL -OF THE AFRICA. THE DIFFIFULTIES BETWEEN THE UNI- PROCLAMATION OF PEACE IN RUSSIA. THE FEACH.

NEW-YORK CITY.; THE USURY LAW. MAYOR'S BLACK BOOK. The Tars Backing up Mayor Wood. The National Poultry Show. Dr. Adams' Church--Renting of Pews. Twelfth Regiment Ball. CHESS. Game at the New-York Club. SHIPWRECKS. A Vessel Ashore. COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS. Board of Supervisors.

docs.snippet: A list of casualties to British shipping has been compiled from Lloyd's List, and laid before Parliament in a blue book. We find that during the last four years there happened at sea 12,363 disasters, varying in magnitude from a total shipwreck to...
docs.lead_paragraph: A list of casualties to British shipping has been compiled from Lloyd's List, and laid before Parliament in a blue book. We find that during the last four years there happened at sea 12,363 disasters, varying in magnitude from a total shipwreck to a slight collision, Some of these times are very striking.

docs.snippet: The clipper ship Staffordshire, Captain RICHARDSON, of and for Boston, from Liverpool, struck on Blond Rock, south of Cape Sable, about 1 o'clock on Friday morning, the 30th ult., and almost immediately went down; carrying with her about one hundr...
docs.lead_paragraph: The clipper ship Staffordshire, Captain RICHARDSON, of and for Boston, from Liverpool, struck on Blond Rock, south of Cape Sable, about 1 o'clock on Friday morning, the 30th ult., and almost immediately went down; carrying with her about one hundred and eighty persons.

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE.; By Telegraph to the New=York Daily Times. DREADFUL SHIPWRECKS. Wreck of the Ship Staffordshire, of Boston. LOSS OF ONE HUNDRED AND EIGHTY LIVES. Effects of the late Storm along the Coast.

docs.snippet: The U. S. Mail steamship Arctic, Captain LUCK, from Liverpool Wednesday, Oct. 19, 11 o'clock, A. M, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, with 220 passengers aud a valuable cargo of foreign goods. Among her passengers are Hen. D. D. BARNARD, o...
docs.lead_paragraph: The U. S. Mail steamship Arctic, Captain LUCK, from Liverpool Wednesday, Oct. 19, 11 o'clock, A. M, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, with 220 passengers aud a valuable cargo of foreign goods. Among her passengers are Hen. D. D. BARNARD, of Albany, late Minister to Berlin, Hon. STEPHEN A DOUGLAS, of Illinois, and the Commissioners from Egypt to the New-York Exhibition.

headline.main: FOUR DAYS LATER FROM EUROPE.; ARRIVAL OF THE AROTIO Official Declaration of War between Turkey and Russia. Neutrality of Austria, Prussia, England and France. FIRMNESS IN THE MARKETS. Rise in Grain-Cotton Firm--Money Market Unchanged, WRECK OF THE BARK HENRY HARBECK. POLITICS AND MOVEMENTS IN FRANCE. ARRIVAL OF THE OVERLAND MAIL Highly Interesting from the Japan Expedition. Interview of Commodore Perry with the Authorities. Departure of the Squadron to return in the Spring. LATEST FROM THE EAST INTERESTING AND IMPORTANT. Gortschakoff's Reply to Turkish Demands--He Refuses to Evacuate the Principalities. LATEST INTELLIGENCE. The Eastern Question. THE EASTERN QUESTION. The Sultan declares War--The Czar accepts it--The Turkish Proclamation--Multitudes of flying Rumors--The position of the Armies on the Danube--Pitched Battle between the Russians and Circassians. The Turkish Declaration of War. GREAT BRITAIN.
